title: The Circle is the best thing to happen to reality TV since Big Brother
text:
The Circle has changed everything (Picture: Studio Lambert)

Circle message: OMG, can’t believe it’s nearly the final. Three kisses. Love heart emoji. Send.

I won’t beat around the bush here: The Circle is the best thing on the box right now, and the best reality competition show for a very, very long time.

I used to be fanatical about this genre of telly. It was so intense in the noughties that when my class did a one-off school newspaper in 2004 and other pupils were covering serious community issues, my friend and I put together a 12-page supplement on Big Brother 5.

But as time has marched on, reality TV as I knew it has been running out of gas; becoming more and more sensational, convoluted and soulless. Aside from occasional gems like Race Across The World and RuPaul’s Drag Race, my enthusiasm for it has sharply dropped.

Advertisement

Advertisement

But The Circle? Oh, The Circle has changed everything. The Circle is everything.

Davina with winner of Big Brother 5 Nadia Almada (Picture: J. Quinton/WireImage)

Yes, I am – and I cannot stress this enough – absolutely obsessed. You know that bit in Mean Girls when Cady’s like, ‘I spent about 80 per cent of my time talking about Regina, and the other 20 per cent of the time I was praying for someone else to bring her up so I could talk about her more’? That’s me with The Circle. ‘I could hear people getting bored with me, but I couldn’t stop!’

At its core, the format is reassuringly familiar to anyone whose Friday nights once revolved around the words ‘this is Davina’. Strangers move in under one roof, are cut-off completely from the outside world, and endure numerous popularity-based evictions en-route to a big cash prize. So far, so standard.

But there’s a twist. Though they’re technically all living in the same building, on this show the players never meet face to face. Instead, they’re confined to separate apartments, and communicate with one-another via a purpose-built, voice-activated app called The Circle.

What this means – and where the show becomes particularly relevant to the social media age – is that contestants can essentially present whatever version of themselves they want… if they even want to play as themselves at all.

Tim, Katie and Woody (Picture: Channel 4)

While many keep things simple and don’t change a thing (eccentric Santa look-a-like Tim, so-called ‘geezer bird’ Ella, 21-year-old firecracker Georgina), others tweak or conceal certain parts of their identity, and others play as completely different characters altogether.

Advertisement

Advertisement

For example, 18-year-old Woody is seeing how far he can get without revealing his parents are Zoe Ball and Norman ‘Fatboy Slim’ Cook, while recruitment consultant James is playing a blinder as he pretends to be a young single mother called Sammie.

Elsewhere, 31-year-old Paddy held off on telling the other players that he has cerebral palsy, wanting them to get to know him for his personality first – something that rarely happens in his day-to-day life. And providing some of the show’s funniest moments, 43-year-old Katie helplessly tried to convince everyone she was her own alpha-lad builder son, Jay.

It’s utterly, utterly engrossing. And what it all boils down to is the fact that, like all good reality TV, it achieves the perfect blend of scream-at-the-telly drama, laugh-out-loud humour, and emotive warmth.

Paddy held off telling other contestants he has cerebral palsy (Picture: Channel 4)

When catfish Katie (as ‘Jay’) obliviously fuelled others’ suspicions with her try-hard hashtags and acronyms, we laughed. When Paddy finally told everyone about his condition, we cried. When Jack and Beth finally kissed after a twist resulted in them playing together as one character, we… well, we weren’t particularly fussed in all honesty, but good for them.

There are payoffs to all the suspicions and deceptions, too. When players get the chop, they can pop in to visit someone else on their way out; and when ‘Jay’ knocked on the door of fellow catfish ‘Sammie’, it was one of the most gasp-inducing scenes of any show this year.

Advertisement

Conversely when best pals Brooke and Georgina met after the former’s elimination, the screams of euphoria when they realised they were both ‘real’ were surprisingly moving.

But an extra string to The Circle’s bow, and perhaps my favourite thing about it, is the fact that we can watch and dissect what happens when people lie about themselves online.

With ruthless 'Sammie' in power as an Influencer, could this be a brutal blocking?! The revolution will be televised on @Channel4 at 10pm. #TheCircle pic.twitter.com/6Yzxr7e8XQ — The Circle (@C4TheCircle) October 16, 2019

When does it make them popular, and when does it not? When does their success or failure say something interesting about society, and when does it just come down to how much effort someone did or didn’t put into a fake backstory?

Emelle, for example, kept her real name and face but aged herself down and hid her sexuality; (worryingly!) assuming she would stand a better chance if the other players thought she was younger and heterosexual.

But instead she was the first to be eliminated when they complained that they didn’t know her well enough. Would she have progressed further if she had unabashedly been herself, rather than a half-baked version? Maybe so.

At the other end of the spectrum, James-as-Sammie shot to the top of the popularity rankings in the early episodes when he realised a gorgeous single mother with a cute baby in her profile picture would easily win others’ affections.

James is playing Sammie, a single mum (Picture: Channel 4)

But after failing to generate much attention beyond that initial ‘aw’, his status slipped. It wasn’t until he started having more fun, letting his own sense of humour shine through via ‘Sammie’, that he returned to the forefront of the show.

Advertisement

And now, with the final in sight, he’s gone all-out ruthless. While he’s loved by some viewers and hated by others, he’s certainly not made the mistakes of ‘Josh’ (Busayo), ‘Joyce’ (Jack and Beth), ‘Jay’ (Katie) and even Emelle by fading into the background with bland or ropey characters.

Clearly, The Circle has given its hooked fans so, so much to talk about in such a short space of time; and with only a few days left, there’s so much more to come.

Whoever wins on Friday (I genuinely can’t pick a favourite), I truly hope it’s back for a third season in 2020 – with the giant ratings it deserves.

Because honestly, with the addictive appeal of Love Island, the drama of Game Of Thrones and the simplicity of a new and updated Big Brother, it really should be sweeping the nation.
